The J-10Câ€™s debut not only showcased its capabilities but also highlighted Chinaâ€™s growing prowess in producing advanced military hardware, raising questions about the shifting dynamics of global air power.

Developed by Chengdu Aircraft Corporation, a subsidiary of the state-owned Aviation Industry Corporation of China, the jet represents a significant leap forward for Chinaâ€™s aerospace industry.

The radarâ€™s precision, combined with the jetâ€™s ability to carry long-range air-to-air missiles like the PL-15, gives it a significant edge in beyond-visual-range engagements. The PL-15, with an estimated range exceeding 200 km, is designed to outrange many Western missiles, making it a critical asset in modern air combat.

The J-10Câ€™s propulsion system has been a focal point of both praise and scrutiny. Early J-10 variants relied on Russian-supplied AL-31FN turbofan engines, but the J-10C has transitioned to the Chinese-made WS-10B engine.
